Communes changed at different times. Oberengadin and Bergel changed in 1783. In Schiers and Grüsch, 25 Dec 1811 was followed by 7 Jan 1812.
Previously used the Thai lunar calendar. The year numbering followed the Rattanakosin Era until 1912, when it was replaced by the Buddhist era; see Thai solar calendar.
The year numbering followed the Rumi calendar until 1 Jan 1926, when the Anno Domini era was adopted.

wikipedia.particulars: The Calendar (New Style) Act 1750 was passed to ensure alignment with the rest of Europe, but made no reference to Gregory.

wikipedia.particulars: Some States adopted as their Common Law the laws of England in 1607, prior to the New Style Calendar Act.[citation needed]

Alaska adopted the Gregorian calendar on incorporation into the United States, which preceded adoption by Russia. The International Date Line was changed, so only 11 days were omitted (a Friday was followed by another Friday).

google.particulars: Albanian Catholics have used the Gregorian calendar since 5 Oct 1583.
In Austria, the Gregorian calendar was introduced in the provinces of Brixen, Salzburg, and Tyrol on 5 October 1583, and in the rest of the country on 16 October 1583.
In Belarus, the Gregorian calendar was introduced in the Duchy of Lithuania on 21 December 1585, and in the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland on 1 January 1586.
Albanian Catholics have used the Gregorian calendar since 5 Oct 1583.
The British colonies in North America adopted the Gregorian calendar on 14 September 1752, omitting 11 days to bring their calendars into line with the Gregorian calendar.
Nova Scotia adopted the Gregorian calendar on 14 September 1752, along with the other British colonies in North America.
The French Colonial Empire adopted the Gregorian calendar on 25 October 1582, following the lead of France.
The Gregorian calendar was introduced in the Kingdom of Bohemia on 5 January 1584, omitting 11 days to bring their calendars into line with the Gregorian calendar.
Austrian Silesia adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1776, following the lead of the Habsburg Empire.
Denmark adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1701, following the lead of the Protestant states of Germany.
Egypt adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1900, following the lead of the Ottoman Empire.
Estonia adopted the Gregorian calendar on 24 February 1923, following the lead of the rest of Europe.
The Faroe Islands adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1701, following the lead of Denmark.
France adopted the Gregorian calendar on 15 October 1582, by order of Pope Gregory XIII.
The Holy Roman Empire adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1700, following the lead of the Protestant states of Germany.
Georgia adopted the Gregorian calendar on 13 February 1918, following the lead of the Russian Empire.
Greece adopted the Gregorian calendar on 24 February 1923, following the lead of the rest of Europe.
Hungary adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1588, following the lead of the Roman Catholic Church.
Iceland adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1700, following the lead of Denmark.
Ireland adopted the Gregorian calendar on 14 September 1752, following the lead of Great Britain.
The Papal States adopted the Gregorian calendar on 15 October 1582, by order of Pope Gregory XIII.
Japan adopted the Gregorian calendar on 1 January 1873, by order of Emperor Meiji.
Laos adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1900, following the lead of France.
The Duchy of Luxembourg adopted the Gregorian calendar on 15 October 1582, by order of Holy Roman Emperor Rudolf II.
Montenegro adopted the Gregorian calendar on 13 January 1919, following the lead of Serbia.
Latvia adopted the Gregorian calendar on 24 February 1918, following the lead of Russia.
Lithuania adopted the Gregorian calendar on 24 February 1918, following the lead of Russia.
Myanmar (then known as British Burma) adopted the Gregorian calendar on 11 January 1886, following the lead of the British government.
